utterances: Absolutely.
(Laughing) Yeah.
I think they'd to keep the study going as long as math teacher - or mathematician ends up number one every time.
We've probably heard more from folks like biologists and industrial designers saying, you know, I think my job's number one, and they've given the rationale as to why.
It's a lot of fun to see people debating over why they think their job is better or why they think their job is worse.
So, if you go to JobsRated.com, we have all those discussions going.
People can contribute as to why they think their job is better or worse.
Let's go to Barry in Arizona.
Hi, Barry.
Oh, hi.
Thank you.
The one issue I have is, like, there doesn't seem to be that many jobs for science and math nowadays.
How can you - how does your Web site help people in those fields?
I have a PhD in the sciences.
Well, a couple of things.
One, the ranking is actually of 200 jobs total, so within the 200, there are actually quite a few more science and math-based jobs.
And then two, our site is actually a job database with hundreds of thousands of positions, and there are thousands of jobs available today in most of these fields.
So, I'd encourage you to go in and take a look.
Craig in Quakertown, PA.
Hi, Craig.
Hey, what's going on?
Hey.
Hey, I have a - I just want to put my two cents in.
You know, the mathematical equation that they came up with had nothing to do with the fact that people are actually happy with what they do for a living.
Yeah, no. That's great.
That is a great point.
And I think the point that we need to make clear is there are people extremely happy doing jobs that no one else would want.
You know, dairy farmer, taxi driver, commercial fisherman are all jobs that landed on our worst list.
Yet, there's some very happy commercial fishermen out there.
This is meant as a guide.
This isn't a definitive, you know, decision - you should not have these jobs.

It's to help primarily those folks who are either going through a career change because they've lost their job or they're unhappy, or students - you know, middle school, high school, college students - who are thinking, you know, I'm debating between this direction or that, you know, which has the best long-term outlook in terms of hiring, the best income, the most - least likelihood that I'm going to get laid off or hurt on the job?
That's what this study is really to be used for as a guide.
Talking about the best jobs in America this hour on Talk of the Nation, Science Friday from NPR News.
I'm Ira Flatow talking with Tony Lee.
Let me see if I can get one quick question in before you go.
(Soundbite of telephone dialing)
(Soundbite of man talking on the phone)
Oops.
Wrong one.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I don't know what happened there.
Next.
Are you there?
Yes, go ahead.
Yeah, I'm a wastewater operator, and I'd like to know where that job falls into.
A wastewater operator.
A wastewater operator is a little too - we only did 200 jobs.
I will tell you that, unfortunately, at a very different level than what you do, but garbage collectors did end up at the bottom of the list.

But remember, if you're a wastewater operator and you're working in a clean environment inside, you're not out in the cold or our in the heat, you've got kind of a controlled environment, and you have control over your day - you don't have fierce deadlines and not someone standing over your shoulder - then it's probably going to rank as a better job, as opposed to a worse one.
Well, Tony, thank you for taking time to be with us today and good luck on the jobs.
Thank you, Ira.
Tony Lee is publisher of CareerCast.com and JobsRated.com.
You can get links to his Web site on our Web site also.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
And I'm Madeleine Brand.
This next story has everything: a stolen identity, a British Lord, Interpol, an American man missing for 23 years.
He may have been a spy.
It only sounds like a thriller though.
It's the real life case of a fake earl.
British authorities have had a man calling himself Lord Christopher Buckingham in custody for the last year and a half.
The real Christopher Buckingham died as a baby in 1963.
The man in custody has refused to say who he really is.
Joining me now is Sean O'Neill from The Times of London.
He and a colleague broke the story as to the bogus earl's true identity.
And Sean, welcome to the program.
Mr.
SEAN O'NEILL (Reporter, The Times of London): Hello.
How do you do?
Fine, thank you.
Well, before we get to who he really is, tell us what happened.
How did he assume this fake identity?
Mr.
O'NEILL: Well, he came to light last year when he was arrested entering the U.K.
on a passport in the name of Christopher Edward Buckingham.
And it seems what Buckingham had done was to assume this identity in much the same way -- I don't know if you're familiar with Frederick Forsyth's thriller, The Day of the Jackal.
Mm-hmm.
Mr.

O'NEILL: But he'd basically gone through the death register to find a child that had died around the same time that he was born, stole that identity and got a copy of that birth certificate, using the birth certificate was then able to create a whole new identity for himself.
He obtained passports, national insurance numbers, bank accounts.
He subsequently married under this name.
He fathered two children.
He promised his son that one day he would inherit the title, you know, Lord Buckingham.
And just blithely for 22, 23 years, went on living this strange sort of Walter Mitty existence.
Okay, and let's get know who he really is.
How did you find out who he really is?
Correct.
Mr.
O'NEILL: Well, we in the U.K.
and in Europe, there are quite a lot of stories written about this guy around November last year, when he was jailed for passport offenses.
Someone who is in the States, in Florida, who had been searching for their missing brother, chanced upon these photographs and stories.
And the likeness in one in particular, in which there's a picture of the young Buckingham with a beard, struck them as very much like their brother who had gone missing 23 years ago.
But what about his wife?
Wasn't she suspicious before this?
Mr.
O'NEILL: She was suspicious because his behavior in the last few years of their marriage was very strange.
He spent more and more time away from home.
But also, he never seemed to answer a straight question.
And when they divorced she made some inquiries.
She placed an advert in our newspaper, actually, saying does anybody know is this Christopher Buckingham?
Seeking information about him.
She also investigated some of the stories he had told her.
For instance, he had told her that his parents were English diplomats who died in a light aircraft crash in Egypt in the early 1980s.
There was no such crash.
There were no foreign nationals who had died in Egypt in any light aircraft crash that year.
So she realized he wasn't who he said he was.
But she didn't know who he was, you know.
That's kind of creepy to think that the man you married and had children with...
Mr. O'NEILL: Yeah.
(Soundbite of laughter)
It's a little different.
Mr.
O'NEILL: Very creepy, yeah.
I wonder if his American accent ever slipped out?
Mr.
O'NEILL: Apparently, his family, the Stopfords in Florida, they say that he could always, from a very young age, mimic a really good English accent.
He was very, you know, could really put on quite an upper class English voice.
So...
And where do the suspicions that he might actually be an American spy come in?
